Award.AwardTitle: Characterization of Polymers with the Kerr-Effect
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY: To more fully understand and improve the properties of polymer materials detailed structure-property relations must be developed to determine how changing the chemical microstructures of polymers effects their behaviors. Establishment of such structure-property relations requires measurement of the properties of polymers with different microstructures, and these micro-structures need to be carefully characterized. The latest NSF Workshop report on Polymers concluded that "recent advances in polymer syntheses leading to elaborate and precise architectures require accompanying advances in microstructural characterization beyond currently available techniques, which are collectively inadequate". Observation of the birefringence that is produced by application of a strong electric field to dilute solutions of polymers dissolved in non-polar solvents with low dielectric constants, ie., electrical birefringence or the Kerr-Effect, may provide a means to more fully characterize polymer microstructures than can be achieved with the currently most sensitive technique, NMR spectroscopy. Molar Kerr constants, mKs, of small molecules including monomers, range over more than four orders of magnitude, and, in addition, may be either positive or negative in sign. mKs of polymers measured from their dilute solutions can be more sensitive to their microstructures than NMR spectra. Because a polymer's mK is a "macroscopic" property characteristic of its entire chain, any microstructural element that alters its overall polarizability tensor or changes the magnitude and/or orientation of its overall dipole moment vector with respect to the direction of its maximum polarizability will effect its mK. Unlike NMR or other spectroscopies dependent only upon local polymer microstructures, the macroscopic positions/locations of microstructures along the polymer chain (middle vs. end) may also effect its mK or Kerr-Effect, thereby permitting identification of the positions/locations of such "elaborate and precise polymer architectures".
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY : The latest NSF Workshop report on Polymers concluded that "recent advances in polymer syntheses leading to elaborate and precise architectures require accompanying advances in microstructural characterization beyond currently available techniques, which are collectively inadequate". The changes in optical characteristics produced by and observed upon application of a strong electric field to dilute solutions of polymers may provide a superior means to characterize the microstructures of their constituent long chain molecules leading to the establishment of improved microstructure-property relations for these materials and their design and optimal application to various end uses. Along with graduate students, undergraduate and high school students will assist in conducting the intended optical property based microstuctural characterizations of various polymers. Each summer a high school student will be mentored under the Project SEED program of the American Chemical Society, which seeks to provide a stimulating summer research experience to encourage underprivileged and underrepresented high school students to go to college and major in a science/technology field. In addition, advancements made in improving structure-property relations for polymers by characterizing their microstructures will be introduced in graduate Polymer Science and Engineering courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal goal of our project was to learn whether or not the Kerr Effect could be used to determine the complete macrostructures of synthetic polymers. This include the types and quantities of local constituent microstructures, as well as their locations along the polymer chain backbones. The worthiness of this goal stems from the fact that the macrostructures of polymers essentially determine how they behave and control the properties exhibited by materials made from them. As an example, the primary sequence or order of the 20 natural amino acid building blocks or monomers in proteins determine how they fold into various 3-D geometrical structures and function biologically. Unlike proteins, whose primary structures or macrostructures can be observed from their genetic DNA, synthetic man-made polymers are not produced with the aid of a readable template. Their macrostructures must be determined post-polymerization on the resulting polymers. This means that an experimental probe that is sensitive to the complete macrostructure of a polymer, and not just the local constituent short-range structural elements it contains is required.

       Our prior investigations of the alignment of polymers in solutions when subjected to the application of strong electric fields, which render them anisotropic, with distinct refractive indices parallel and perpendicular to the applied electric field, suggested that this electrical birefringence or Kerr effect might be useful to probe synthetic polymer macrostructures. As a consequence, we synthesized several polymers and received several others from collaborators,  all of which contained the same types and quantities of local short-range microstructures but had distinct macrostructures, for the purpose of determining whether or not the Kerr Effect could distinguish them.

         As an example, the tri-block copolymers, pBrS90-b-S120-b-pBrS90 (I) and   S60-b-pBrS180-b-S60 (II) shown in the attached Figure, were synthesized and the electrical birefringence observed on their dilute dioxane solutions when strong electrical fields were applied. Though preliminary, these Kerr constant measurements indicated that  both triblock copolymers have Kerr constants of similar magnitude, but with  positive and negative values for triblocks (II) and I, respectively. This dramatic difference is observed despite both tri-block copolymers having the same overall comonomer composition and number of identical block junctions. Because they differ only in the locations of their S and pBrS blocks, comparison of their observed Kerr constants clearly indicates that the Kerr effect may be used not only to identify polymer microstructures, but also to locate them along the macromolecular chain backbone leading to identification of their macrostructures.

Many additional polymer samples with the same microstructures, but that were located differently to yield distinct macrostructures were examined with the Kerr Effect. In all cases their different macrostructures resulted in distinct Kerr constants, which could be used to identify them. Now, for the first time, we have the means to begin to unravel the complete backbone architectures of synthetic polymers. This is a capability that will enable more relevant structure-property relationships to be developed and should lead to the syntheses of polymers that can be processed into superior materials.
